displayed_text: Patient: Anyway… Doctor: You’re gonna need that. When is the neurosurgeon appointment? Patient: Next week. Doctor: Okay. Alright because I think we are going to have to hold off a lot of decisions then for their input. Patient: If there’s a decision to be made I mean… Doctor: About your treatment, yeah. If it’s surveillance it’s easy because we’re sort of… Patient: Oh yeah. That’s the best case scenario. Doctor: …then the cancer is giving us a break and you can deal with your… Patient: Right other stuff. Doctor: …neck issue and spine and penis issue too. Laughs]] Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now that we’re on tape let’s document this. It’s real. You have to face it.

Family Member: I may have to go sign an order. Doctor: He wrote down the questions? That’s pretty good. Family Member: Well, yeah. I mean, I am his daughter. (Laughs) Doctor: Does that mean it’s going to execute. I mean. Patient: I’m not as thorough as she is about things. My notes are really basic. Patient: Okay. What are some of the things that I should really be on the lookout for, the fatigue? Doctor: I think really just the tiredness. If you feel like you’re more off balance, you know, let’s say it’s weeks from now, that’s something also that’s pretty subtle that can come up just like that (snaps) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. It’s almost just like, you know, you stand up and you’re ooh. Not like it’s spinning, but you just don’t have a sense of where you are, and then you right yourself, but, obviously, we don’t want you to fall. Um, so if you start to feel like, you know, there’s some unsteadiness, we need to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a lot of paperwork if you fall.

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, so they randomize you to just standard treatment, then you wouldn’t get the- Patient: There’s seventy percent I will get the real thing? Doctor: Two out of three. Yes. Yeah. Patient: Hum. But, uh, for some reason I want to quit or couldn’t make anymore, I could just stop? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. If you’re not tolerating it or if there are issues, yeah. Patient: I don’t think I’d have any trouble tolerating. Doctor: Yeah. It doesn’t seem like, from everything I’m gathering about this medication, it seems like it’s been easy to tolerate. There may be some infusion reaction or, you know-. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Some occasional side effects, but we’ll be monitoring your blood labs, liver function, kidney function, all of that, every time before we give you that injection. Family Member: So- Doctor: So you’ll be monitored.

Patient: …the Provenge, the pheresis. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Never. Just so you know. Doctor: The other option is chemotherapy and chemo… Patient: For prostate? Doctor: For prostate and that is actually FDA approved also. Patient: Hm, I did not know that. Doctor: Yes and it’s one drug called Taxotere and it’s given through the IV so usually either arm… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …once over one hour every three weeks. Patient: Hm, okay. Doctor: Okay? We do have a study coming up doing that, plus vitamin C high dose. Patient: Really?

Patient: That’s what I’m like, that’s what I was trying to tell you. That’s the way he didn’t know what I take. He said you still taking the prednisone Doctor: So you need a new script? Patient: Yeah I need a new script, all of that. Doctor: Because even with this new chemo I need to continue the prednisone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m telling you. Patient: Okay. Okay Doctor V____. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I’m I’m doing anything you want me to. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I’m good. Doctor: Okay so we’ll be back with all that paperwork and stuff. Okay?

Patient: The ARV seven has to stay positive and, uh, (stuff) Doctor: Right. Next time you come in, we’re gonna be in a new building. Patient: Oh boy! Doctor: Across the street. Family Member: Are you sort of surprised he’s not in pain? Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Uh, the – we always ask about pain, you know. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, because pain does mean -- pain means we gotta do something now. Family Member: I get it. Doctor: Most people don’t have pain. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Did you get your certificate? Doctor: My certificate? Patient: From the U_______. Doctor: I did! How did you know that? (pause) Patient: I – You you want me to be the best patient you’ve got, I… Patient: I have to know all that stuff. Doctor: Thank you. I’m now officially the Rudi Ansbacher academic scholar at U______. Patient: Good for you. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: This this comes from The Art of War by Doctor: Oh man! Patient: Always occupy… Doctor: That was in the battleship movie.

Patient: There’s the first one is – is whoops, one of them is from um March of fifteen to um November of fifteen and then the second one is January of sixteen to March of seventeen. Doctor: Okay. And I forgot, I think I asked you this before, do you have a nephrologist? Patient: No. I do not. Doctor: This is your primary care person checking it right? Patient: Yeah. But whoever was doing – ordering the vitals. Doctor: Yeah, gotcha. Patient: The vitals, the vitals, the uh what do they call it, comes in a comprehensive uh metabolic, metabolic panel. Doctor: Yeah, you were as high as one point seven five, May twenty-sixteen? Patient: No I think in fifteen I was even higher than that. Doctor: And then um (papers shuffling) Patient: I don’t know that your medication is the one that’s the problem. Doctor: It’s probably not.

Patient: And so this is gonna show us if if it worked? Doctor: Yeah so the CAT scan I think one of our concerns was that you also had the lymph node disease. Patient: Right. Yeah. Doctor: And at the last time that we did it before we started the Xofigo, really the lymph nodes were not a part of the problem. Okay. So assuming that the lymph nodes are still well controlled and everything, then I don’t think we need to do any further treatment. We’re sort of in watch and wait monitor mode. Patient: Right. Doctor: If, however, the lymph nodes are growing or other areas that non-bone disease is showing progression, then we’ve got to address it. Patient: Start chemo or… Doctor: Yes xxx]. Patient: They don’t do um radiation to the lymph nodes. Doctor: They could, but you know the problem is… Patient: It spreads. Doctor: xxx] right. Yeah. Yeah, it’s not one lymph node that’s remaining. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said. Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like-

Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril.

Patient: Well and… Doctor: Here’s the thing you got to take the medication. Patient: You want me to start to take a look at the Norco again or? Doctor: I think you should and just don’t let it get out of control you know, like I’d rather you take it occasionally or all the time if you need to. There’s no right or wrong on that. Family Member: It’s not that bad. Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. So if you know for example, you’re just having a hard time sleeping, then just take your Norco at night so that way you can get a good night’s rest. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you know listen at night I’m not bothered I sleep like a rock, then take it when you first get up so that you can function. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Or you get up and it’s tolerable but now it’s the early afternoon, you still have more stuff to do, you’ve got family, you’ve got friends, there’s a barbeque, so take some, just a small amount… Patient: Sure.

Patient: I mean, not, and please no, no offense. Doctor: No. No. Patient: Oh, yeah. I mean he I consider him part of my team. Doctor: Absolutely. Me too. Patient: You know? Doctor: Me too. Me So. Patient: I have great confidence in him as I do with you, but as you know. Doctor: Yep. No. I was picking his brain. Patient: You’ve got to ask twice. You know? Doctor: Every time. Every time. Patient: You know? Doctor: So he says hello and he’s happy you’re doing well. It’s just trying to a –

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So we might as well get an impression of what the bones, what’s going on in the lower back, and all of that, as well as mainly the lymph nodes is what I want to keep an eye on. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I think maybe the Xofigo is still doing its stuff. Patient: Um hum. Yeah. Your husband did a good job. Doctor: As long as everything is in remission. Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: On and off, I guess I’ll compliment him, then. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Right. Right. Yeah. Not too much. Doctor: Not too much. Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Everything went okay and smoothly? Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. I’m fine. Yeah. Patient: So we get the shot right here?
